Program Cluster 
 
 

The Government’s ultimate goal is to restructure school education into 
an  integrated  1–12  school  system.  Since  this  would  require  a 
systematic and sustained period of analysis and planning, in 2004 the 
Government  requested  technical  assistance  from  ADB  to  develop  a 
holistic, programmatic approach for grades 1–12.  
 
The current international commitments to EFA and other programs will 
end  by  financial  year  (FY)  2009.  A  new  5-year  planning  cycle  will 
begin in 2007 with the Eleven Five Year Plan. Following the changes 
in the political context since April 2006, including a possible end to the 
10-year  armed  conflict,  Nepal  is  poised  to  enter  a  period  of 
development that will include education restructuring. As the causes of 
the  conflict  were  rooted  in  social,  economic,  and  political  disparities, 
post-conflict development policies and priorities will affect the direction 
for  education  reform.  The  restructuring  and  reform  of  the  education 
system  will  need  to  be  integrated  and  egalitarian,  rather  than 
fragmented and elitist. The timing is opportune for the Government to 
start  preparing  for  inclusive  and  holistic  school  sector  reform. 
Preparation  of  the  1–12  school  system  reform  and  restructuring  plan 
has begun and it is proposed that ADB should continue to support the 
preparation  of  and  transition  to  the  1–12  school  system  through 
education  policy  capacity  development  and  sector-wide  program 
development.  
 
The  proposed  program  cluster  for  the  Education  Sector  Program 
(ESP)  will  offer  phased  support  for  the  Government  of  Nepal’s 
medium-  to  long-term  education  sector  reform  and  restructuring.  The 
expected  outcome  will  be  a  more  equitable,  inclusive,  effective,  and 
holistic  education  system.  Three  subprograms  will  be  developed  and 
implemented  in  accordance  with  the  timeframe  and  progress  of  the 
education sector reform and restructuring from 2007 to 2012.   
 
Subprogram I (ESP I) will help implement policy interventions in basic 
and  primary  education  by  supporting  EFA,  2004-2009.  It  will  help 
prepare  an  education  reform  and  restructuring  program  that  aims  to 
integrate  the  current  primary  and  secondary  subsectors  into  an 
integrated grade 1–12 school system.  
 
Subprogram  II  will  support  initial  implementation  of  the  1–12  school 
system  reform  and  restructuring,  particularly  an  early  implementation 
of 1–8 basic education restructuring in a few districts.  
 
Subprogram  III  will  support  the  phased  implementation  of  the 
restructured 1–12 school system.

The  program  loan  will  support  Nepal  EFA,  2004–2009  and  the 
achievement  of  the  six  EFA  goals:  (i)  early  childhood  development 
(ECD)  expanded;  (ii)  access  to  education  for  all  children  increased; 
(iii) learning  needs  of  all  children  met;  (iv)  adult  literacy  improved; 
(v) gender  and  social  disparities  eliminated;  and  (vi)  all  aspects  of 
quality  education  improved.  The  program  loan  will  provide  budgetary 
support  to  the  EFA  through  the  JFA.  It  will  help  finance  the  3 
remaining  years  of  EFA,  and  to  monitor,  assess  and  improve  EFA 
implementation  with  other  development  partners.  It  will  support  a 
range  of  policy  interventions  to  (i)  increase  equity  of  access  to 
education and social inclusion; (ii) improve quality and relevance; and 
(iii) enhance efficiency and institutional capacity.        
 

  Financing Plan     A  loan  equivalent  to  $30  million  in  special  drawing  rights  from  ADB’s 
Special  Funds  resources  will  be  provided.  The  loan  will  have  an 
amortization period of 24 years, including a grace period of 8 years; an 
interest  rate  of  1%  per  year  during  the  grace  period  and  1.5% 
thereafter;  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  as  set  forth  in  the 
Loan Agreement.  
 
Subprogram  II,  which  will  be  presented  separately  for  consideration 
and  approval  by  the  Board,  and  will  depend  on  progress  with 
subprogram I, is expected to require a grant of $8 million from ADB’s 
Special Funds resources.  
 
Subprogram  III,  which  will  be  presented  separately  for  consideration 
and  approval  by  the  Board,  and  will  depend  on  progress  with 
Subprograms  I  and  II,  is  expected  to  require  a  loan  and  grant  of 
$25 million from ADB’s Special Funds resources. 
 
The Program period will be from January 2007 to July 2009. The loan 
closing  date  will  be  January  2010.The  loan  will  be  released  in  two 
equal  tranches  of  $15  million  each.  The  first  tranche  will  be  released 
upon  loan  effectiveness.  All  the  first  tranche  conditions  have  been 
met. The second tranche is expected to be released within 18 months 
of  the  release  of  the  first  tranche,  subject  to  compliance  with  the 
second tranche release conditions.

effectiveness,  a  project  steering  committee  (PSC),  chaired  by  the

technical secretariat and consultants. 
 
The Project will be implemented over 3 years from 1 January 2007 to 
31 December 2009. Grant closing date will be 30 June 2010. 
 
The  selection  and  engagement  of  all  consulting  services  to  be 
financed  under  the  Project  will  be  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants.  The  Project  will  finance 
approximately  9  person-months  of  international  and  112  person-
months  of  national  consulting  services.  The  consultants  will  be 
selected  by  ADB,  and  engaged  and  supervised  by  MOES.  The 
consultants recruited under the Project (package B) will procure the IT-
related equipment, and the goods required for the refurbishment of the 
technical secretariat and the policy resource room in accordance with 
the ADB's Procurement Guidelines. The shopping method will be used

The  overall  impact  of  ESP  I  will  be  stable  progress  toward  a  more 
equitable  and  effective  education  system.  The  education  benefits  and 
impacts of ESP I will generate social benefits among socioeconomically 
disadvantaged  groups.  Better  access  to  an  affordable  and  quality 
education, and better learning achievements will ensure that such groups 
will  be  able  to  generate  the  necessary  education  and  social  capital  to 
build  economically  and  socially  responsible  lives.  An  egalitarian  and 
inclusive education system can help to relieve the root causes of conflict 
and social tension, build social cohesion and bring social stability. Better 
access  to  post-primary  and  basic  education  of  girls  and  women  will 
enhance  women’s  political,  economic,  and  social  roles.  As  EFA 
emphasizes inclusion, conflict mitigation, and post-conflict reconstruction, 
ESP  I  will  contribute  immediately  to  implementation  of  the  inclusion 
strategy and will intensify the role of education in peace building.

the implementation risks of this program loan are low. Operating in the 
conflict-affected  areas  used  to  be  a  major  issue,  but  as  security  has 
improved  EFA  will  be  able  to  reach  poor  and  disadvantaged 
communities in those areas. A potential financial risk is that an existing 
development partner may decide not to continue. However, this risk is 
considered  small  because  the  current  development  partners  have 
been  consistent  in  their  support  for  Nepal’s  education  sector.  Should

THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 

 
Nepal’s  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  per  capita  was  less  than  $200  during  the  three 
2.

improvement was inequitable, exacerbating gender, ethnic and geographic disparities.

Government Policies and Programs    

 
14. 
Policy Trends and Shifts. For several decades, Nepal has anchored education policy on 
the principle that expanding human capital is the key to economic progress. The goal of education 
was  to  expand  schooling  through  higher  enrollment,  a  greater  budget  share,  higher  teacher 
qualifications,  and  more  teacher  training.  This  policy  was  successful  in  expanding  the  supply  of 
schools.  However,  a  large  gap  has  persisted  in  education  opportunities  among  children  of 
disadvantaged groups. In addition, increasing the number of schools and providing more teacher 
training have not, in themselves, improved students’ performance.  
  
15. 
The  Government  introduced  fundamental  policy  changes  after  2000:  (i)  it  promoted 
equity  of  access  and  social  inclusion  as  a  national  priority,  and  (ii)  it  emphasized 
decentralization and community involvement in education. The Tenth Plan reflects these policy 
changes.  For  the  first  time,  the  5-year  plan  has  social  inclusion  as  one  of  its  four  pillars  and 
emphasizes inclusive education as a central approach to reducing disparities related to gender, 
caste,  and  ethnicity.  The  Tenth  Plan  also  defines  decentralization  as  the  centerpiece  of  its 
school improvement strategy. It promotes decentralization of school governance by proposing to 
provide  school  management  responsibilities  to  school  management  committees  (SMCs)  at 
individual  schools.  Furthermore,  the  seventh  amendment  to  the  Education  Act,  2001  provides 
communities, through the SMCs, formal rights in the management of primary schools. In 2000, 
Nepal joined the global movement Education for All (EFA). The National Plan of Action for EFA 
2015  was  drawn  up  with  the  vision  of  achieving  quality  basic  and  primary  education  for  all  by 
2015. The National Plan of Action also set a long-term vision for extending basic education to 
grade 8 and ultimately to develop a holistic school education system covering grades 1–12. 
 
16. 
Future  Policies  and  Reforms.  Given  the  changes  in  the  political  context  since  April 
2006  and  the  possibility  of  ending  the  10-year  armed  conflict,  Nepal  is  poised  to  enter  a  new 
period of development that will include education restructuring. Although it would be premature 
to  predict  how  the  sociopolitical  situation  will  evolve,  it  is  likely  that  post-conflict  reform  will  be 
strongly  oriented  to  addressing  the  social,  economic,  and  political  disparities  that  caused  the 
conflict. It is also likely that the current policy of decentralization will be strengthened, and that 
participation,  equity,  and  inclusion  will  remain  fundamental  goals  so  the  education  system

18. 
Education  for  All,  2004–2009.  EFA  started  as  a  follow-up  to  the  Basic  and  Primary 
Education Project II from 1999 to 2004,4 which was also financed by a number of development 
partners,  and  the  adoption  of  the  EFA  National  Plan  of  Action  2015.  EFA  is  a  high-priority 
program  supported  by  more  than  11  development  partners.  Guided  by  the  international  EFA 
movement  and  the  Tenth  Plan’s  policy  direction,  the  EFA  “core  document”  is  the  sole  policy, 
strategy,  program,  and  financing  framework  for  the  Government  and  development  partners  in 
basic and primary education. EFA, 2004-2009 is estimated to cost over $800 million, with over 
70%  provided  by  the  Government.  It  has  six  goals:  (i)  early  childhood  development  (ECD) 
expanded; (ii) access to education for all children increased; (iii) learning needs of all children 
met; (iv) adult literacy improved; (v) gender and social disparities eliminated; and (vi) all aspects 
of  quality  education  improved.  EFA  is  Nepal’s  first  truly  program-based  approach  (PBA)5  and 
involves full development partner harmonization. Under a joint financing arrangement (JFA), five 
development  partners6  pool  funds  for  earmarked  activities  through  an  annual  strategic 
implementation  plan  (ASIP)  and  the  AWPB.  These  are  agreed  by  the  Government  and  the 
development  partners  before  the  beginning  of  each  fiscal  year.  Other  development  partners 
provide parallel financing to EFA. A development coordination matrix is in Appendix 3.

Medium-Term Policy Objectives and Outputs  

 
35. 
Under  the  Tenth  Plan’s  overall  policy  direction,  the  EFA  core  document  introduces  a 
range  of  policy  interventions  to  improve  (i)  social  inclusion  and  equity  of  access  to  education; 
(ii) the quality and relevance of education; and (iii) efficiency and institutional capacity. ESP I’s 
program loan will support the continued implementation of these policy interventions. 
 
Social Inclusion and Increased Equity of Access to Education. The policy objective 
36. 
is to remove economic, social and cultural barriers to participation in primary education through 
targeted  interventions.  An  expected  policy  output  is  wider  access  to  free  primary  education. 
Although  primary  education  is  free  as  mandated  in  the  Education  Act,  in  practice,  direct  and 
indirect costs of education are a major economic barrier for poor households. Key interventions 
include (i) scholarships17 targeted at the poor, girls, Dalits, vulnerable communities, and children 
with  disabilities;  and  (ii) prioritized  recruitment  of  female  teachers  to  achieve  the  target  of  one 
female teacher per primary school. Gender and social equity awareness is included in teacher 
training. EFA promotes a more conducive learning environment through the construction and/or 
improvement of school facilities.    
 
37. 
Improved  Quality  and  Relevance  of  Education.  The  policy  objective  is  to  improve 
teacher  qualifications,  training  and  deployment;  textbook  and  educational  materials;  and 
curricula. The expected outputs are improved availability of qualified and trained teachers, more 
availability  of  relevant  educational materials,  curricula  that  meet  the  learning  needs  of  all,  and 
the  introduction  of  school-based  assessment.  The  Government  has  made  10  months  of  in-
service  teacher  training  mandatory  for  all  primary  teachers.  This  certificate-based  training  is 
provided  through  TEP.  In  addition,  teachers  receive  follow-up  in-service  training.  The 
Government  is  currently  reviewing  a  proposal  to  secure  timely  distribution  of  textbooks.  It  has 
introduced  a  policy  that  20%  of  the  curricula  should  be  local  content  in  order  to  introduce  life 
skills and to reflect local needs and culture.   
 
38.

EFA  is  the  decentralization  of  school  governance.  Responsibility  for  school  management  has 
been gradually transferred to SMCs, with a view to improving quality, efficiency, and institutional 
capacity.  The  expected  outputs  are  that  SMCs  and  communities  will  be  better  able  to  plan,

The formula-based school grant system is a key element of the decentralization policy. 
The Government intends to transfer 60% of non-salary budget to SMCs as grants by 2009. SIP 
and school grants provide the financial basis for SMCs to plan and manage school affairs. The 
earmarked  grants  are  intended  for  teacher  salaries,  free  textbooks,  and  scholarships.  Three 
types  of  block  grants  are  provided.  General  block  grants  cover  administrative  costs,  basic 
learning  materials,  and  incentive  grants  to  community-managed  schools.  SIP  grants  are 
allocated to implement SIPs and can cover quality and physical improvement needs, non-salary 
recurrent costs, capacity development needs, and support for children’s access to and retention 
in  schools.  SIP  grants  are  allocated  according  to  the  number  of  students,  with  additional 
allowance  made  for  Nepal’s  relatively  backward  regions.  Performance  grants  are  rewards  to 
schools  based  on  performance  indicators  such  as  85%  Grade  5  survival  rates  and  30%  of 
female or Dalit teachers.

the  Government  decided  to  return  schools  to  decentralized  community  management  on  a

particularly those groups which have been denied a quality and affordable education in the past. 
It  will  help  achieve  the  six  EFA  goals  by  meeting  part  of  the  financing  gap  and  by  providing 
technical  advice  and  capacity  development  to  improve  EFA  implementation.  Education  policy

A. 
 
In  1951,  there  was  space  in  Nepal  primary  and  secondary  schools  for  only  10,000

population  now  attends  primary  school  (grades 1–5),  46.5%  at  lower  secondary  (grades  6–8), 
32%  at  secondary  (grades  9–10),  and  13%  at  higher  secondary  (grades  11–12).  There  is  an 
increasing demand for post-primary education. The average annual growth rate for the number 
of  primary  schools  during  1995–2005  was  2.5%,  for  lower  secondary  it  was  5.3%,  and  for 
secondary it was 6.6%. However, despite these remarkable achievements, access to education 
varies greatly by region, income, gender, ethnicity, and caste, and there is a lack of quality and

2. 
About 15% of students enrolled in grade 1 are under-age, and 24% of the grade repeats 
the  year.  Although  survival  rates  have  improved  over  the  years,  20%  of  students  do  not 
complete primary school. Less than 50% of the students who begin primary school enter lower 
secondary  school  and  even  fewer  enter  higher  secondary  school.  Gender,  caste,  and  ethnic 
disparities in enrollments increase with the level of education, and poverty plays a key role. Only 
5% of secondary students and less than 1% of university students are from the lowest income 
quintile. Dalit girls have the poorest performance at all levels. 
 
3. 
The  public  education  system  is  ineffective.  Students  answer  less  than  one-half  of 
answers  correctly  in  grade  3  and  grade  5  achievement  tests.  The  pass  rate  for  students  from 
public schools in the grade 10 school leaving certificate (SLC) exam have ranged from 25% to 
35% over the past decade. In 2004, SLC pass rates improved to 46%. However, while 82% of 
private school students pass SLC examinations only 34.6% of public school students do so. The 
low achievement of public school students is generally attributed to lack of inputs: inadequately 
trained  teachers,  long  delays  in  the  delivery  of  textbooks  and  learning  materials,  shortages  of 
teachers in some areas, inadequate funding, and delayed provision of funding to schools.

4. 
Nepal  has  experimented  with  community-owned  and  managed  schools  (1950–1970), 
state-managed  schools  (1970–2001),  and  privatized  schools  (1990–present).  In  2001  the 
Government decided to return schools to community management on a gradual and voluntary 
basis, in the hope this would improve their quality and help to share costs. In 2005, there were 
about  1,700  community-managed  schools.  There  are  three  types  of  schools  in  Nepal:  aided 
community  schools,  un-aided  community  schools,  and  institutional  (private)  schools.  While 
aided community schools receive government funds for teachers’ salaries and other operational 
costs,  until  recently  un-aided  community  schools  received  funds  only  for  operational  costs. 
However,  they  now  receive  grants  to  enable  them  to  hire  two  teachers  per  school.  Aided 
community  schools  still  receive  grants  for  teachers’  salaries,  but  management  responsibility, 
including  recruitment  of  teachers,  has  been  transferred  to  the  school  management  committee 
(SMC).  
 
5.

the national level. Resources are transferred from the Ministry of Education and Sports (MOES) 
directly to schools. MOES also monitors school performance and performs fiduciary functions.

C. 
 
7. 
For  the  past  50  years  Nepal  has  anchored  its  education  policy  on  the  principle  that 
expanding human capital is the key to economic progress and raising living standards. Because 
schooling plays an important role in the expansion of human capital, each national development 
plan  has  set  explicit  expansion  targets,  such  as  higher  enrollment,  a  greater  budget  share  for 
education, higher teacher qualifications, and more teacher training. This model was successful 
in  expanding  the  supply  of  schools.  However,  increases  in  student  attendance  have  not 
necessarily  improved  Nepal’s  human  capital  stock.  The  persistent  problem  has  been  that, 
despite significant growth in access to and demand for education, many public schools are not 
effective.   
 
8. 
Fundamental  Reform  Model.    After  2000,  Nepal’s  education  policies  shifted  toward  a 
renewed emphasis on decentralization and community involvement in education. These reforms 
sought to change the relationships of authority and accountability among stakeholders.  Within 
the broad spectrum of education for poverty reduction as reflected in the Tenth Five-Year Plan, 
2002-07, the national educational goal is to develop an effective and equitable public education 
system for grades 1-12. The major strategy adopted by the Tenth Plan is the decentralization of 
school governance by providing school management responsibility to SMCs and, accordingly, to 
change the role of district and central level agencies from controller to facilitator.   
 
D. 
 
Despite policies, programs and projects based on local and international best practices,

inefficiencies  that  drain  resources  and  the  absence  of  a  holistic  approach  to  the  entire  school 
education  sector.  At  the  school  level,  policies  aimed  at  improving  efficiency  are  often  not

10. 
Effective  Schools.  Quality  improvement  has  been  a  concern  in  Nepal  for  the  past  20 
years. During the 1980s and 1990s several large projects were launched to improve the inputs 
to  and  performance  of  public  schools.  These  efforts,  although  successful  in  meeting  their 
targets,  have  been  less  effective  in  creating  an  effective  school  system  in  the  long  term.  In 
2005,  many  schools  were  still  unable  to  provide  a  minimum  standard  of  service.  Standards  of 
learning  and  minimum  expected  learning  outcomes  need  to  be  defined  in  terms  that  are 
practical and realistic for Nepal’s resource constraints and needs.  

 
11. 
Accountability.  The  defined  obligations  of  government,  teachers,  schools,  and 
communities are not enforced and there are no consequences for failure to perform to minimum 
standards.  This lack of accountability undermines efforts to improve school quality.  
 
12. 
Sectorwide  Policy  Framework.  The  Tenth  Plan  articulates  a  human  resources 
development  plan  that  includes  an  integrated  1–12  school  system  with  many  exit  points.  At 
present, MOES does not have a policy framework that addresses the 1–12 school sector as an 
integrated  whole.  As  a  result,  differences  of  interpretation  at  lower  levels  combine  with 
ambiguity  at  the  national  level  to  send  confusing  messages  to  stakeholders.  This  hampers 
implementation and prevents efficient use of resources. Examples of policy areas that warrant 
attention include teacher management, setting of minimum standards, school finance, and the 
need for a clear assignment of school governance and management functions.    
 
Emerging  Policy  Directions.  Education  is  not  only  a  technical  and  administrative 
13. 
process, but a political and social one. Changes in the broad socio-cultural, economic, or public 
administration  contexts  impact  deeply  on  policies,  programs,  and  implementation.  After  the  
change  in  the  political  landscape  in  April  2006,  it  is  likely  that  fundamental  challenges  to  the 
current  model  of  education  provision  will  be  raised.  There  will  be  an  opportunity  to  reexamine 
the sector as a whole and to construct a responsive education policy framework that is aligned 
with a new Constitution. New governance, finance, and education laws will need to be drafted 
and  passed.  The  Government  will  have  to  shape  a  governance  and  finance  structure  for 
education that is appropriate for a restructured, reformed, and more inclusive school system.

Crosscutting Themes 

Decentralization. Nepal is decentralizing education through community management of 
14. 
schools, block and earmarked grants for school financing, and school recruitment of teachers. 
However,  there  are  several  unresolved  issues  affecting  school  governance  and  management 
under decentralization: (i) some functions, such as teacher management, have been assigned 
to  both  schools  and  districts;  (ii) some  functions  are  unclear,  e.g.,  the  responsibility  for 
monitoring  schools  by  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs),  communities  or  supervisors; 
(iii) responsibility,  but  not  authority  or  resources,  has  been  assigned  to  making  SMCs 
responsible  for  school  improvement  planning;  and  (iv)  there  are  no  consequences  for  not 
fulfilling functions, e.g., teachers who do not attend school regularly are not disciplined.

School  Financing.  At  the  school  level,  financing  of  operational  costs  has  shifted  to  a 
15. 
formula-based block and earmarked grant mechanism. The allocation of grants is based on the 
submission of a school improvement plan (SIP) by the SMC to the DEO and follows criteria set 
out  in  the  school  grant  operation  guidelines  of  the  DOE.  For  instance,  while  all  schools  that 
submit the SIP receive a basic grant, some are allocated  a larger grant, based on the number 
of  students  and  the  geographical  area.  There  are  also  detailed  allocation  criteria  based  on 
performance.  The  challenge  in  implementing  the  guidelines  is  the  complexity  of  some  criteria, 
such  as  the  numerous  types  of  scholarships,  which  makes  it  difficult  for  stakeholders  to  fully 
understand or  apply  them.  Some  criteria  for performance  grants  are  difficult  to  attain,  such  as 
those  based  on  survival  rates,  which  means  very  few  schools  can  take  advantage  of  such 
grants.   
 
The notion of formula funding is to provide schools with funds rather than inputs and to 
16. 
base  allocations  on  a  formula  rather  than  on  an  ad  hoc,  incremental,  or  school  budget  basis. 
Although there are many advantages to this approach, there are also conceptual and practical 
problems.  In  practical  terms,  formula-based  grants  introduce  schools  to  two  new  ideas  at  the 
same time: the formula part and the cash transfer part. Because formulas are not transparent, 
head teachers and SMCs do not know how much they are supposed to receive and they often 
draw  up  school  budgets  based  on  needs  rather  than  anticipated  cash  transfers.  Schools  are 
accustomed to being provisioned rather than financed, and purchasing goods such as textbooks 
and  services  such  as  teacher  training  can  be  difficult  for  them.  Finally,  formula-based  block 
grants  place  the  responsibility  for  accounting,  bookkeeping  and  auditing  on  the  schools,  and 
many are unaccustomed to this administrative burden. 
 
F. 
 
17. 
Current  long-term  national  and  subsector  financing  plans  do  not  address  some  of  the 
key issues related to the transition to a 1–12 school system, nor have they taken into account 
the  fact  that  financing  for  grades  6–12  is  inadequate  to  support  anticipated  demand  for  post-
primary  education.  Expansion  is  not  planned;  the  current  practice  is  for  schools  to  grow  one 
grade at a time as local resources permit, then to request assistance from the Government after 
the  fact.  The  planned  restructuring  of  school  education  from  the  current  primary,  lower 
secondary,  secondary,  higher  secondary  subsectors  to  an  integrated  1–8  (basic)  and  9–12 
(secondary) structure will require systemic changes in governance, management and financing 
structures and has serious implications for investment and management of human and physical 
resources.  
 
18. 
As part of preparations for the Education Sector Program I (ESP I), the DOE projected 
national  level  student  enrollment  and  teacher  requirements  for  primary,  lower  secondary  and 
secondary  levels  for  2006-2012.  The  projection  involved  making  assumptions  on  population 
growth rates, grade 1 intake rates, transition rates, and the proportion of public schools. As the 
Government plans to fully implement the policy of automatic promotion of grade 1 to 2 in 2007, 
and as it is estimated that gross intake rates (GIR) will decrease gradually, the number of grade 
1  students  should  gradually  decrease.  The  primary  gross  enrollment  rate  (GER)  will  go  down 
sharply  after  2010,  and,  in  turn,  the  lower  secondary  GER  will  go  up  when  students  in  the 
current grade 2 cohort move from the primary to the lower secondary level.  
 
19.

at  the  primary  level.  Teacher  vacancies  at  lower  secondary  level  are  estimated  to  be  2,000–
6,400,  and  at  the  secondary  level  to  be  1,200–3,900.  There  are  regional  imbalances:  while 
about half of the mountain and hill districts suffer from severe teacher shortages, the rest have

6. 
 During EFA appraisal in 2003, the program was assessed to be financially sustainable, 
on  the  assumption  that  the  Government  will  gradually  increase  total  expenditure  on  education 
from  15%  of  the  total  budget  to  18%  by  FY2009  and  that  it  would  increase  its  share  to  basic 
education from 55% to 60%. The MTEF V forecast suggests that the Government will increase 
education’s share of the total budget to 18%. Based on the assumption that the Government will 
increase its share, the EFA appraisal included an overall program plan, based on two scenarios 
for  development  partner  contributions:  (i)  a  low  case  of  $145  million,  and  (ii)  a  high  case  of 
$175 million. In both cases, most recurrent expenditures are met by the Government. However, 
the activities under development expenditures in the low case scenario are smaller scale.           
 
The EFA core document recognizes the risk to financial sustainability posed by the weak 
7. 
fiscal  balance  and  the  uncertain  sociopolitical  situation.  The  commitment  by  existing 
development  partners  to  EFA  is  high,  and  provided  the  sociopolitical  situation  continues  to 
improve, the Government expects more partners to join the Program. ESP I will close some of 
the immediate funding gap. However, more robust financial planning will be required to ensure 
effective implementation during the last year of the EFA.                   
 
D. 
 
The  EFA  appraisal  made  an  assessment  of  EFA’s  financial  sustainability  beyond  the 
8. 
program period based on an enrollment projection (without an extension to grade 8).4 According 
to the appraisal, the EFA will be financially sustainable beyond FY2009, on a base case scenario 
of  4.5%  annual  GDP  growth,  education  expenditure  at  3.5%  of  GDP,  and  55%  of  expenditure 
allocated to basic and primary education.   
 
9. 
In  the  absence  of  a  comprehensive  sector  financing  plan,  it  is  difficult  to  assess  the 
financing shortfall of the total school sector. However, from the broad estimate made by DOE of 
the  sector  from  FY2006  to  FY2009,  it  is  unlikely  that  Government  alone  can  meet  all  the 
financial  requirements.  The  ESP  I  feasibility  study  made  a  projection  of  requirements  for 
teachers, based on an enrollment projection from 2006 to 2012. This suggested there would be 
serious teacher shortages at the primary level in the next few years, but the problem will expand 
and shift towards the lower secondary and secondary levels as the present cohorts in primary 
schools  move  to  the  higher  grades.  The  Government  needs  to  thoroughly  review  the  present 
teacher  deployment  situation  across  regions,  schools,  and  education  levels,  and  to  make  a 
realistic action plan for teacher redeployment that maximizes the use of its limited resources.  
 
10. 
The Government has substantially increased its investment in education, particularly in 
primary education, since the early 1990s. Primary enrollment has rapidly increased to achieve 
EFA,  and,  consequently,  secondary  enrollment  has  increased  and  will  increase  further.  Given 
the  rapid  expansion  of  primary  and  secondary  education,  it  is  likely  that  Nepal  will  need 
considerable financial support from its development partners over the next 5–10 years for EFA 
and beyond EFA, particularly if the current slow economic growth rate continues. At the same 
time, the Government needs to develop strategies to help schools and communities to mobilize 
funds  at  the  school  level,  and  to  encourage  the  development  and  involvement  of  the  private 
sector  wherever  possible.  The  EFA  core  document  rightly  recognizes  the  need  for  continued 
external support in the sector in the medium to long term. It reiterates that investment in primary 
and  secondary  education  is  crucial  to  reduce  persistent  poverty  and  inequality,  and  that  such 
investment will help bring social and political stability, increasing the economic returns of such 
investment in the long term.

1. Rationale. The development rationale of the 1–12 school sector reform and restructuring basic education is that the 
present  10  years  of  schooling,  including  5  years  of  primary  education,  is  inadequate.  8  years  of  basic  education  is 
considered  the  minimum  to  perform  civic  duties  diligently  and  to  engage  productively  in  occupations.  Secondary 
education prepares candidates for the job market as members of a skilled workforce. An equitable and strong 9–12 
secondary  education  is  required  to  minimize  the  restricted  access  to  secondary  education  caused  by  systemic 
bottlenecks. A combined 9–12 system will enable more candidates to complete grade 12. The structural integration of 
grades  1–5  with  6–8  will  enable  curricular  integration,  leading  to  a  competency-based  learning  program. 
Consolidation will make teachers, head teachers, and SMC training more efficient.  A 1–8 basic education structure 
will have a positive impact on teacher management and development. An integrated 1–12 school sector will help the 
Government  and  its  development  partners  determine  Nepal’s  human  development  goals,  needs  and  resource 
requirements in a holistic manner. The Education For All NPA, 2001–2015 emphasises the need to harmonize school 
education by integrating the 1–12 school system. The Tenth Five-Year Development Plan, 2002-07 (the Tenth Plan) 
stresses the need to adopt a holistic approach to the school sector.

a. School Structure   

3.  Objectives.  The  objective  of  school  sector  reform  and  restructuring  is  to  make  school  education  effective, 
inclusive, equitable, pro-poor, and rights-based. The objectives of the school sector approach (SSA) are to: (i) provide 
a policy framework to facilitate the reform process for an integrated school sector; (ii) enhance all aspects of quality 
education to meet the needs and aspirations of the people; and (iii) hold the Government, local bodies, schools, and 
stakeholders (e.g., SMC, teachers, parents, and local body) accountable for student learning. 
4. Policy Directions  
 
 
School  education  will  comprise  grades  1–12.  Basic  education  will  be  grades  1  to  8,  and  secondary  9  to  12.    The 
vocational  education  stream  will  begin  at  grade  9.  After  completing  their  3  years  of  education,  vocational  stream 
students  will  be  given  opportunities  to  enter  tertiary  education  by  completing  an  additional  1-year  bridging  course. 
Students who are enrolled in non-formal education programs can obtain certificates through school equivalency tests. 
Formal  and  non  formal  education  will  be  made  compatible  to  permit  students  to  complete  their  education  through 
either system.  
 
 
Within  the  education  sector,  the  relationships  of  authority,  accountability,  and  responsibility  between  the  national, 
sub-national, and local levels will be fully aligned with any restructuring of the overall governance systems.  
 
 
Schools for basic education and secondary education will be encouraged to operate as separate entities in terms of 
their management, administration, and financing. Schools will teach either primary or secondary grades. Provisions of 
alternative programs—such as out-of-school, flexible learning, and open or distance learning—will cater to the needs 
of a diverse population of learners. These alternatives will provide access to school education to a wider population 
with special needs, such as street children and children from migrant communities.  
 
 
The  basic  education  will  be  free  and  compulsory  for  children  between  the  ages  of  6  and  14.  Children  currently 
enrolled  in  schools  will  continue  to  receive  the  entitlement.  Free  education  will  cover  basics  such  as  admission, 
textbooks,  tuition,  and  examinations.  Secondary  education  will  be  provided  on  a  cost-sharing  basis.  However, 
arrangements will be made to ensure free secondary education to children from disadvantaged communities.

Schools will be managed in a decentralized way. The emphasis will be placed on school-based management, which 
will  be  accountable  to  a  local  body.  The  schools’  accountability  and  autonomy  will  be  ensured  in  terms  of  school 
governance, management, resourcing, and quality assurance.  Schools  will follow a transparent model of operation 
and will adopt a mechanism for social auditing for financial transactions and programme performance. Local bodies, 
such as VDCs and municipalities will be responsible for the planning and management of basic education. DDCs and 
municipalities  will  be  responsible  for  the  planning  and  management  of  secondary  education.  DDC  planning  and 
management activities will include school clustering, coordination, resourcing, and developing operational guidelines, 
including  setting  their  own  targets  for  quality  education.  The  SMC  will  be  responsible  for  the  management  and 
operation of the school.  
 
 
The overarching strategy for the SSA will be social inclusion. Special attention will be paid to increasing participation 
of  women,  Dalits,  members  of  ethnic  minorities,  disabled,  and  marginalized  groups  in  the  management  of  schools, 
and to increasing the number of teachers from these populations. 
 
 
Teaching  modalities,  such  as  grade  and  multi-grade  teaching,  will  be  determined  by  the  school  management  in 
consultation with the local body and within nationally defined guidelines.  
  
 
A child’s mother tongue will be employed as the medium of instruction up to grade 3. To ensure that children learn in 
their mother tongue, the SMC will determine the language(s) of instruction in consultation with the local bodies such 
as  DDCs  and  VDCs.  Grades  4  and  5  can  follow  a  transition  from  the  mother-tongue  medium  of  instruction  to  the 
Nepali  medium  of  instruction.  From  grades  6  to  8,  the  medium  of  instruction  will  be  fully  in  Nepali.    English  will  be 
taught as a subject from grade 4. In secondary education the medium of instruction will be determined by the SMC in 
consultation with the DDC or  municipality through the DEO.   
 
 
SMCs will recruit teachers from among those who obtained teaching licenses, based on guidelines provided by the 
MOES. SMCs will adopt competitive and transparent selection procedures to recruit teachers. The MOES will issue 
directives for teachers’ service conditions. Priority will be given to recruiting females, Dalits, and other disadvantaged 
groups when filling teacher positions, particularly in basic education. The minimum qualification for teachers of basic 
education will be graduation from the Higher Secondary Education or Intermediate Level. During the interim phase, 
candidates with SLCs will be considered on a case-by-case basis. New entrants in secondary education must have 
attained  a  master’s  degree,  or  an  equivalent  qualification.  During  the  interim  phase,  candidates  with  bachelor’s 
degrees  will  be  considered  on  a  case-by-case  basis.  Teachers  currently  working  in  the  primary  schools  with  SLC 
qualifications and in secondary schools with a bachelor's degree will be provided with training opportunities to enable 
them to meet the minimum requirements. After the interim phase, incentive packages for voluntary retirement will be 
provided  for  teachers  who  do  not  meet  the  new  minimum  requirements.  Provisions  will  be  made  to  prepare  a 
separate  cadre  of  teachers  specializing  in  multi-grade  teaching.  Specific  terms  and  conditions  for  multi-grade 
teachers  will be developed. Two separate professional career development paths  will be offered: one for basic and 
one  for  secondary  teachers.  Teachers’  qualifications  and  performance  will  be  linked  with  their  career  development, 
including their salary structure. 
 
 
A separate position for head teacher will be created in full-fledged 1-8 and 9-12 schools. In 1-12 schools, there will be 
one head teacher and a separate level from among the teachers will be designated in-charge of basic and secondary 
education. The head teacher's job will be technical, managerial, and administrative in nature. SMCs will appoint head 
teachers on a contractual basis. The terms and conditions of the head teacher will be determined by the MOES.   
 
 
Basic education provisions will be the responsibility of the state. The role of private schools in basic education will be 
gradually reduced. The role of the private sector will be encouraged in ECD and secondary education. Attention will

schools) will be encouraged to provide free education. Again, attention will be given to ensuring adequate access to 
disadvantaged  populations.  Partnerships  between  public  and  private  institutions  in  secondary  education  will  be 
encouraged.

5. Structural and Functional Adjustment  
 
 
MOES will be accountable for policy formulation, follow-up, coordination, and review and monitoring. The central level 
Ministries  and  agencies  will  be  responsible  for  facilitating  program  implementation  and  coordination.  The  regional 
education directorates will be made responsible for the conduct of the regional level grade 10 examinations and will 
provide support for the grade 12 school leaving examinations. They will also be coordinating with the Teacher Service 
Commission activities. The district education offices will be responsible for making logistical arrangements for school 
governance,  management,  planning,  financing,  quality  assurance,  and  the  education  management  information 
system  (EMIS).  A  sub-district  level  mechanism  will  be  established  and  will  be    responsible  for  teacher  support  and 
quality enhancement. The SMC will be responsible for teacher management, financing, planning, target setting, and 
for  ensuring  student  learning.  The  parent  teacher  association  (PTA)  will  be  responsible  for  providing  feedback  to 
teachers.  Parents  will  be  responsible  for  providing  support  and  a  home  environment  conducive  to  their  child’s 
learning. 
 
 
To enhance the quality of learning in schools, their performance must be regularly reviewed. There should be regular 
feedback  and  rewards.  Such  reviews  will  help  to  establish  a  system  of  accountability  and  transparency  and  to 
encourage  the  school  system  to  adopt  more  targeted  and  needs-based  interventions.  The  review  office  will  be  an 
independent body under the EPC of the MOES. As an extension of the review office, district level review panels will 
work  in  collaboration  with  teacher  unions,  SMCs,  PTAs,  teachers,  and  other  professionals.  The  resource  centre 
system will support schools that need special attention in terms of technical support and resources.

The Government’s poverty reduction strategy (PRSP) is the Tenth Five-Year Development Plan, 2002-07 (the Tenth 
Plan). It recognizes the critical role of education in poverty reduction and aims to reduce the overall poverty incidence 
to  30%  by  2007,  and  to  significantly  improve  the  living  conditions  of  the  poor.  The  PRSP  is  built  on  four  pillars:  (i) 
broad-based  economic  growth;  (ii)  human  development;  (iii)  targeted  programs  to  foster  social  inclusion  of  the  very 
poor,  vulnerable,  and  historically  deprived  groups;  and  (iv)  good  governance.  ADB’s  country  strategy  and  program 
(CSP) 2005–2009 for Nepal is based on the Government’s strategic priorities as set out in the Tenth Plan and focuses 
on promoting broad-based economic growth, inclusive social development, and good governance.  

The biggest problem facing education in Nepal is the lack of universal access to effective education.  Some schools 
are  disadvantaged  because  they  are  affected  by:  (i)  the  internal  conflict;  (ii)  the  income  level  of  the  parents; 
(iii) disparity in gender, ethnic and caste participation; (iv) shortages of teachers; and (v) regional disparity. There are 
disparities in infrastructure, basic services, libraries, teaching and learning materials, level of teacher training, lack of 
qualified teachers, and ability to raise funds for school development.   
 
Private schools perform better and their results at the school leaving certificate (SLC) examination are better. Public schools 
suffer  from  poor  learning  environments,  inadequate  teaching  facilities,  and  weak  performance  of  teachers,  especially  in 
remote areas. These schools lag behind in term of performance. Public school students come from low- income families, 
while private schools cater to those who can afford to pay. To achieve poverty reduction in Nepal, the key challenge is to 
improve the quality and efficiency of public education. The quality of education is low in most rural areas. Schools in these 
areas  often  do  not  possess  basic  requirements,  such  as  water,  sanitation,  and  libraries. Although  education  is  free,  poor 
parents  are  often  unable  to  meet  other  expenses,  such  as  uniforms,  writing  materials,  transportation  costs,  and  the 
opportunity  costs  of  sending children  to school.  Poor  students  have  limited access to  quality  education  in public  schools, 
which results in significant inequity between the poor and the better off who attend private schools. 
 
ESP  I  will  increase  social  benefits  among  socially  and  economically  disadvantaged  groups.  Better  access  to  an 
affordable  quality  education  will  ensure  that  such  groups  will  be  able  to  generate  the  education  and  social  capital 
needed to build economically and socially responsible lives. A shift to an egalitarian and inclusive education system 
will mitigate the root causes  of conflict and  social tension,  build social cohesion, and  bring social stability. Improved 
access to post-primary and basic education for girls and women will enhance women’s role in political, economic, and 
social spheres.

Nepal’s  per  capita  income  is  $280  per  annum.  Human  development  indicators  are  poor.  A  large  section  of  the 
population  has  little  access  to  basic  social  services.  Nepal  has,  however,  made  significant  progress  in  human 
development and in reducing poverty in the past decade. Poverty incidence is estimated to have declined to 31% in 
2004. In the Kathmandu Valley, the poverty rate is only  4%, but in rural Nepal it is  10  times higher. It is even more 
severe in the most remote regions (72% in the mid and far western regions). Similarly, social and human development 
indicators,  such  as  life  expectancy,  infant  and  maternal  mortality  rates,  the  adult  literacy  rate,  and  primary  school 
enrollment have all improved significantly in the past decade. 

The 59 recognized indigenous ethnic groups, identified on the basis of linguistic and socio-cultural characteristics from 
the dominant Hindu caste population, comprise about 37% of the population. “Dalit” is a collective term for so-called 
disadvantaged castes (about 15% of Nepal’s population). There are large income disparities related to gender, caste, 
and ethnicity. Generally, households headed by women have lower incomes than those headed by men. On average, 
the earnings of Dalits are less than half of those of members of upper caste groups. Indigenous ethnic groups earn 
only slightly more. Such disparities are not confined to economic factors, as there are significant regional inequalities. 
Human development indicators (HDIs) for rural areas are 30-40% lower than for urban areas. HDIs for Dalits are only 
about half of those of the upper caste groups and HDIs for ethnic groups are only slightly better. Almost two thirds of 
Nepalese  women  cannot  read  or  write,  compared  with  one  third  of  men.  Females  receive  only  half  the  number  of 
years of schooling received by males.

Extensive  evidence  from  South  Asia  shows  that  female  education  generally  promotes  labour  force  participation  and 
higher  wages  for  women,  especially  if  women  reach  secondary  and  higher  levels  of  education.  It  also  encourages 
smaller,  healthier  and  better  educated  families  and  enhances  women’s  own  wellbeing.  Studies  have  shown  that 
increasing the proportion of girls with secondary level education corresponds with fewer early marriages, reduced infant 
mortality rates, and greater participation of women in family decisions.  Because female education helps slow population 
growth while raising the productivity of the present and future generations, higher female enrollment at the primary level 
and longer schooling will promote faster growth of per capita income. Given the enormous returns to female education, it 
is essential that the Government of Nepal maintains a strong focus on increasing access for women and for retaining girls 
in primary and secondary schools, particularly those from poor and disadvantaged families.a  
 
National  policies  in  Nepal  promote  gender  equality  and  guarantee  women’s  human  and  fundamental  rights.  However,
